title: What is the difference between the words 'kindly' & 'please'? - Quora

response.answer_text: What is the difference between please or kindly? And where to use? “Please” is an abbreviation for “If it pleases you … .” or, at an intermediate level of abbreviation, “If you please.”. This interpretation implies that the following phrase is a request, and the person addressed is to feel free to deny the request. “Please” is sometimes used in an emphatic tone, in which it carries the additional meaning “This is highly important to me.”. (In this context, it might be more appropriately spelled “pleas”, as if “I am pleading.”, but that is not standard practice.) However, it then retains the meaning that “You have the right to refuse.”. “Kindly” means that the person addressed would increase the happiness of the requester by complying, but the following phrase is a command with the same force as if that adverb had been omitted. It is often used ironically, with emphasis on the adverb, to mean “If you comply, we will remain on good terms; otherwise, I will force your compliance.”. This is according to my experience in Canada, and in North American and European literature. I cannot speak for Indian job recruiters, but I suspect that an applicant who refuses to comply will be dropped from consideration.

It’s largely one of register. “Please” is the normal, natural word to make a request polite. “Kindly” is not normal, sounds a bit contrived, and I can think of two uses. The first is in tortured commercial-speak: “We request our customers to kindly put their baggage in the overhead lockers” (now I’m on the aeroplane I’m a passenger BTW), or even “We kindly request our valued customers….” The other is when you're being a bit snarky: “Could you give me a bit more room, please?” means “There’s no reason you should have realised this, but if you move along a bit we can all be comfortable, thank you, <smile>.” “Could you kindly give me a bit more room” means “Stop your bloody manspreading, recognize that other people have rights, and stick to your own seat.” My perspective is that of an old Brit with a middle-class education: YMMV.

Both “kindly” and “please” can be used as adverbs as in , “ Please finish this task today itself” (which is formal and no emotions involved) or, “ Kindly recommend me for a suitable promotion in my next appraisal” (which is semi-formal, with a strong emotional note.) In corporate and business circles, “please” is the preferred choice whereas in social interactions, “kindly” is preferred more often. “Kindly” can also be used as an adjective ( E.g. She is a kindly old lady) whereas “please” cannot be used in the role of an adjective. “Please” can also be used as a verb ( E.g. Please yourself with a sumptuous breakfasts) whereas “"kindly” cannot be used as a verb. “Please” use the word “kindly” when you want to express your “meaning” plus your “feeling” !

I’d say that the Indian job recruiters are using a style that, in British English, in 2017, could be considered a little old fashioned or overly formal: “Would you kindly send your CV to the above address”(or whatever), instead of the more general “please send”. In that context “kindly” means exactly the same as “please”. I occasionally use “thank you kindly for….”(whatever) in written communication, instead of simply “thank you” or “thank you very much”. It’s just a matter of not wishing to express things always in exactly the same way. I agree with Mark Harrison’s comment that “kindly” can also be used in a more sarcastic or contemptuous way, in conversation, depending heavily on tone of voice - but that would not apply in the context you are describing.

Take care over the use of the word “kindly” because it can be used as a form of insult or ticking-off if used at the end of a letter or on a Notice. As in:“Kindly do not spit on the floor” gives a hint of the reproving schoolmaster. Or “Kindly do not urinate on the grass”. Compare this to: “Please do not spit on the floor.”…which makes it sound far more acceptable and polite.

Q: “What is the difference between please or kindly? And where to use?” I find that Indian job recruiters have a tendency to use “kindly” instead of “please” when requesting that I send my résumé/CV, so there’s probably a cultural thing going on in Indian usage. It is not correct in American English, where “please” is the correct word. As I noted in my comment to Mark Harrison’s answer, “kindly” is an adjective, as in “a kindly old woman”.

He was a kindly old man. That didn't please me. They can be synonyms but in context can be quite different and be different parts of speech. Depending on delivery, even with the same basic meaning they could convey subtler differences such as sarcasm, rudeness, etc that the alternative might not if substituted in the same sentence.
In British English, you always use “please.” The only exception is when you are wanting to appear polite, but actually express contempt. You need to be very, very, English to get away with this.

I suppose there is a little difference in “tone”, but I think you can use either judging what suits the body of the letter. Maybe “kindly” is a little softer and shows more gratitude, but does it assume if you don’t do it… you are not kind? “Please” is definitely more formal. I would not use “kindly” in a business letter. Good question!

“Please” is used more in casual & spoken English while “kindly” would be more formal way of communicating particularly in official letters. I don’t think there is a rule that really specifies any difference.
Almost no difference. E.g.: Please answer the question. AND: Kindly reply to my question. SO: Take your pick.
